page.title: 06Stanwell_Local History
page.content: The parish church of St Marys is a large and fine building, it is much larger than any other neighbouring village church. It contains all varieties of 'English Gothic Architecture'. In 1863 it was restored. A new porch was added and the north aisle rebuilt. If you look at the spire from different places you can see that it is out of perpendicular. On the south wall of the chapel, a piscina, and a pew of eight seats, these were probably placed there by Chertsey Abbey. In the church are some Norman features, especially an enriched south door, the chapel arch and a small window in the chapel. Recently discovered on the wall representing the crucifixion and the last Judgement, was a carving in wood
